data.title: Women Who Colored Outside the Lines: An International Women’s Week Tribute
data.meta_description: For want of a clear starting point, let’s just say this project began when I decided to focus my writing on women artists for the remainder of 2022. Women are starting to break down barriers and…
data.text:
For want of a clear starting point, let’s just say this project began when I decided to focus my writing on women artists for the remainder of 2022. Women are starting to break down barriers and stereotypes in music all over the world, and I wanted to celebrate that.

One of the biggest stereotypes being challenged today can be summed up as “Girls don’t play guitar.” How can women be considered fully empowered, musically, if they are only permitted one mode of expression, one kind of musical vocabulary?

Yet that is exactly what has happened in American popular music.

Today, women in American popular music (which includes everything from pop to hip-hop) are largely confined to the singer-songwriter lane (with a few dramatic exceptions, some of whom I have written about). Looking back at our musical history canon, it would seem like it was always that way. The great female stars of jazz, swing, and blues were all singers — at least the ones we hear about.

Back then, people would say, “Girls don’t play the drums…” Or piano…Or trumpet… The message was the same.

Only, it wasn’t actually that way. There were great female composers, bandleaders, and instrumentalists in the ’20s, ’30s, and ’40s. Then, after the Second World…
